body_text.text: The unprecedented access to annotated genomes now facilitates the investigation of the molecular basis of epigenetic phenomena in phenotypically diverse animals. In this critical review, we describe the roles of molecular epigenetic mechanisms in regulating mitotically and meiotically stable spatiotemporal gene expression, phenomena that provide the molecular foundation for the intra-, inter-, and trans-generational emergence of physiological phenotypes. By focusing principally on emerging comparative epigenetic roles of DNA-level and transcriptome-level epigenetic mark dynamics in the emergence of phenotypes, we highlight the relationship between evolutionary conservation and innovation of specific epigenetic pathways, and their interplay as a priority for future study. This comparative approach is expected to significantly advance our understanding of epigenetic phenomena, as animals show a diverse array of strategies to epigenetically modify physiological responses. Additionally, we review recent technological advances in the field of molecular epigenetics (singlecell epigenomics and transcriptomics and editing of epigenetic marks) in order to (1) investigate environmental and endogenous factor dependent epigenetic mark dynamics in an integrative manner; (2) functionally test the contribution of specific epigenetic marks for animal phenotypes via genome and transcript-editing tools. Finally, we describe advantages and limitations of emerging animal models, which under the Krogh principle, may be particularly useful in the advancement of comparative epigenomics and its potential translational applications in animal science, ecotoxicology, ecophysiology, climate change science and wild-life conservation, as well as organismal health.

Epigenetics research has transformed conceptual and methodological approaches in all fields of biology, including comparative physiology. Because of the contextually divergent historical use of the term "epigenetics" (Burggren and Crews, 2014; Nicoglou and Merlin, 2017) , the definition of what encompasses epigenetics has been the subject of some debate (Deans and Maggert, 2015) . In the field of comparative physiology, the current conceptual focus of epigenetics includes emergent properties of phenotypic plasticity including phenotypic intra-and inter-individual variation in response to environmental and endogenous cues across an organism's ontogenesis, life-cycle, and its descendants (Burggren and Crews, 2014) , with potential significance for evolution (Crews and Gore, 2012; Guerrero-Bosagna, 2017) . Several molecular epigenetic mechanisms have been the focus of investigation in this dynamic field ( Fig. 1 ) and encompass both DNA-level transcriptional control (histone modifications and chromatin structure and DNA methylation) as well as post-transcriptional mechanisms (small and long non-coding RNAs including miRNAs and piwi-interacting RNAs, as well as RNA methylation, more recently referred to as the epi-transcriptome) (Li et al., 2016; Peer et al., 2019) . Together, these mechanisms regulate spatiotemporal gene expression and shape subsequent function independently of changes in the nucleotide sequences (mutations). Molecular epigenetic marks are mitotically and meiotically stable and therefore play important roles in manifestation of physiological phenotypes across ontogeny (e.g. somatic cell differentiation), and across generations by acting on germ cells (Wu and Sun, 2006; Hanson and Skinner, 2016) . With the unprecedented and continuously growing availability of genome sequences and annotations across the animal kingdom, the emerging field of comparative epigenetics has the potential to greatly advance our understanding of how molecular epigenetic mechanisms act within different genomic contexts to shape diverse physiological phenotypes within and between generations of different species.
body_text.section: Epigenetics and animal physiology: a brief primer

body_text.text: In this critical review, we define a theoretical and technical experimental framework for future comparative investigation of epigenetics to study animal physiology, and highlight important knowledge gaps and questions as focal points for future research. We also highlight novel original research which rigorously investigates intra-generational epigenetic phenomena at the transcriptional and posttranscriptional levels. In addition to its study in basic physiological sciences, a role for epigenetics in shaping phenotypes is increasingly acknowledged in the applied context of a variety of economically important domesticated terrestrial animals and aquaculture species (Gavery and Roberts, 2017; Thompson et al., 2020) . This is reflected by original research contributions to this special issue which explore the role of brain areaspecific DNA methylation patterns in naturally emerging behavioral variation in Brown Nick Hens (Guerrero-Bosagna et al., 2020) , the role of miRNA networks in the regulation of rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss) hepatic energy metabolism in response to social and nutritional challenges (Kostyniuk and Mennigen, personal communication) , and the role of exosome miRNAs in the stress response of the same species (Cadonic et al., 2020) . The comparative epigenetic framework has also increasingly spurred research applicable to ecotoxicology. This is exemplified by a study in which zebrafish were exposed to the aquatic pharmaceutical pollutant venlafaxine under different temperature regimes, revealing how both anthropogenic and naturogenic influences interact to affect a molecular epigenetic mechanism in the zebrafish ovary (Ikert and Craig, 2020) .
body_text.section: Epigenetics and animal physiology: a brief primer

body_text.text: Our goal is that this critical review and special issue will serve as a call to further advance research into the role of epigenetic regulation and function in diverse animal physiological phenotypes through an integrative comparative approach. Here we point out that epigenetic mechanisms act upstream of gene expression, and epigenetic marks do not necessarily lead to phenotypic change. Thus, assessing responses over several levels of biological organization is critical for characterizing phenotype. The review is organized by first introducing specific mechanisms of epigenetic change, followed by examples from different animal taxa highlighting the mechanism under discussion. This is followed by specific challenges and opportunities for scientific advance in comparative epigenetics.
body_text.section: Epigenetics and animal physiology: a brief primer

body_text.text: DNA level epigenetic transcriptional regulation involves mechanisms that regulate gene transcription through direct modification of nucleotides or histone proteins, which act to compartmentalize certain regions of the DNA (Bártová et al., 2008) . Histone proteins package eukaryotic genomes as euchromatin or heterochromatin, broadly defining DNA regions that are active or suppressed in transcriptional activity. Conversely, DNA methylation involves the addition of a methyl group to cytosines, rendering promoters and genes themselves inaccessible for the transcriptional machinery (Doerfler, 1983) . A class of enzymes (e.g. methyltransferases, acetyltransferases) act to add and remove functional groups to DNA nucleotides or histone proteins, orchestrating fine-tuned control over the timing and patterns of gene expression. This control underlies fundamental biological processes such as development, reproduction, metabolism, and other aspects of physiology and behavior. Most important perhaps is that such modifications can be transferred to subsequent generations potentially preparing offspring for uncertain or harsh environments. However, these transcriptional modifications can also be "reprogrammed" due to anthropogenic (e.g. chemical) and abiotic (e.g. temperature, hypoxia) environmental stressors (Dorts et al., 2016) . It is clear that DNA level epigenetic transcriptional regulation is a crucial phenomenon in understanding physiological acclimation/acclimatization and, potentially adaptation, that warrants scientific investigation in comparative animal models.

Histones are proteins that effectively wind and compartmentalize DNA by forming a series of interacting dimers in the nucleosome. They contain N and C-terminal regions or "histone tails" which are modified by phosphorylation, ubiquitylation, methylation, acetylation (He and Lehming, 2003) , and other modifiers that are not yet well characterized. The binding and packaging of the DNA is modulated by histone tails modification, which at the end determines DNA accessibility and activation/deactivation of transcription in a time dependent fashion. The two most prevalent classes of enzymes involved in histone modifications are histone acetyltransferase (HATs) and histone deacetylase (HDACs) (Nakao, 2001; Hayakawa and Nakayama, 2011) . HATs (now referred to as lysine acetyltransferases (KATs)) add acetyl groups to histone tails, whereas HDACs remove acetyl groups from histone tails. This is achieved using acetyl-coA as a donor to yield acetylated proteins. Once acetylated, euchromatin becomes accessible and transcription can occur. The use of HDAC inhibitors is used as a tool to maintain transcriptionally active chromatin regions. Multiple proteins/protein families have been demonstrated to mediate histone modifications (Rando, 2012) , such as CREB-binding protein, and E1A Binding Protein P300 (EP300) for histone acetyltransferase; histone deacetylase 4, histone deacetylase 6, and histone deacetylase 8 for histone deacetylation; Enhancer of zeste homolog 2, (Euchromatic Histone Lysine Methyltransferase 1), and Histone-lysine N-methyltransferase 2A for histone methylation to name but a few.

We know comparatively little in non-traditional animal models regarding the dynamic organization of the nucleosome core and associated linker regions, an area of study that is needed to improve our understanding of the timing of DNA transcription. Currently the state of the science in comparative animal physiology is at the point where the community is beginning to identify and quantify the expression patterns of these enzymes in various non-rodent/human animal models. For example, a recent study in the mangrove rivulus (Kryptolebias marmoratus) revealed a number of histone deacetylase (HDAC) and lysine acetyltransferase (KAT) genes and predicted the structure of KATs to determine conserved domain organization of their sequences (Fellous et al., 2019) . Moreover, in the study, sequence data from chicken, frog, zebrafish, pufferfish and other teleost fishes were used to generate a phylogenetic analysis of rivulus KAT proteins. This study also included real-time PCR analysis of the relative mRNA levels and expression patterns of the different enzymes in early developmental L. Navarro-Martín, et al. Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology -Part D 36 (2020) 100745 stages as well as adult tissues. The authors concluded that there was a dynamic pattern of expression during development, with some of the HDAC genes not expressed, while others showing peak expression during organogenesis. Studies such as these will be extremely useful moving forward in comparative animal studies.
